It's not a bad game, but I can't recomend it in general.
Graphic didn't age well. Environment design is not good either. You see alot of metal and warehouse with wooden boxes. Sometimes the enemies appear infinitely. So you can waste all your ammo until you close the hole with a car (where they comming from). Fighting the mines and waiting the flash light to reload kinda feels tedious.
I can only recomend it to hardcore fans of Half Life.

Ну чтож, мои кривые ручёнки добрались и до этого, простите.                                                                                    (Я дико нг)
-------------------------------------------------Half life 2 Episode 1-----------------------------------------------------------
Саундтрек - 10\10, передаёт отмосферу игры. Физика 9\10 иногда трупы проходят сквозь приграды. Геймплей 10\10 на свой год. Наличие багов  9\10 всё таки нашёл 1, это неправильный спавн врага. подача сюжета - 10\10.
------------------------------------------------------Итоги---------------------------------------------------------------------
Игра получилась знатная и прошла мою критику. Я вам рекамендую вам эттот замечательный проект! Всего доброго!

[b]Half-Life 2: Episode One[/b] is really good, but there are two questions you should answer before buying it.

[olist]
 [*] Have you played [b]Half-Life 2[/b]? This is a direct sequel, and rather assumes you know the NPCs already.  The original game is also great, so playing it is no cost.  Also, if you [i]don't[/i] like HL2 you won't enjoy this either.
 [*] Are you willing to play an unfinished story? As you should know, this was intended to be the first of three episodes making a complete game, and Episode Three has never been, and likely will never be, released.  Indeed, the only people I can understand not wanting to play this are those who can't leave stories unfinished.
[/olist]

It's a shame, because HL2:E1 has a lot to recommend it even compared to other HL games.  The chance to play with the supercharged Gravity Gun again is welcome. The option to set Zombies on fire is always a plus.  We learn more about the Combine here than in all of HL2, and also get to learn more about Alyx.  This game even manages to make an escort mission somewhat enjoyable!

Really, the Half-Life series is excellent, and the Episodes would be indisputably the highlight, if only the third had been released.  But I'd still recommend it to nearly everyone.

Another great addition to the Half-Life series.

As the games creep suspiciously closer to Portal, the first half of this was more of an action puzzler.

The gravity gun is definitely in full effect. Then they throw a quick round of enemies on you for the final few chapters, so you get some of your familiar weapons back.

Nothing new here like Half-Life: Opposing Force, but definitely a different style of gameplay to be had.

Definitely recommend playing this if you enjoy 2.

Well this game has almost nothing new.. and that's the best thing about it!

It's more direct and contained. For better or worse there are no more vehicles sections and this time Alyx is with you most of the time. She is one of the few companions I enjoy and really like her being around.

The horror section is done very good. One of the best level ever.

All in all this is a prime example where little new additions are actually better than to add, change or overhaul big aspects of the game. By little additions I mean new enemy types, new obstacles and a new mission type. Instead of vehicle section you now have an escort section.

Anyway Half-Life 2: Episode One is as it should be.. :)

You want Half-Life 3? Then do this:

- Don't pay for microtransactions in any game like TF2, CS:GO or Dota 2

- Don't buy Steam Trading Cards

- If you want, don't sell your cards either

- Actually, don't buy or sell anything from the Community Market

- If you want an item from a game, use the original trading and not the market

- Don't craft badges with the trading cards

- Don't buy games on Steam just for the trading cards

- Buy Half-Life games

Half-Life 2: Episode 1 is the first in an unfinished, yet concluded, trilogy of games in the post-launch of Half-Life 2 to continue the storyline similar to the execution of the Blue Shift and Opposing Force expansions of Half-Life 1 with one continuity. These are as much of expansion packs in the epilogue of the Half-Life 2 campaign as they are an entirely new game broken into parts. Episodic models of the mid-2000s did not have as bad of a reputation as they do nowadays with the idea of unfinished games, and the episodes of Half-Life are example of the benefits of its model as well as the possible downsides. As much complaints people have with Episode 1 due to its length and its linearity that focuses on the well-executed scripted levels of the base-game like Ravenholm and Nova Prospekt, EP1 manages to take the best parts of the gameplay of HL2 into a game that does a better job masquerading its tutorials as they shifted the focus on the combat rather than the puzzles.

Before we continue with the review of Episode 1, as a reminder I will not be discussing the recent leak about Half-Life 2: Episode 3 until we get to the end of the Half-Life 2: Episode 2 review. This review mainly serves as a retrospective view of Episode 1 to follow-up my review of Half-Life 2, so if you want my thoughts about that section of the game or the end of the series then it’s best to read the review associated with it. EP1 should be remembered not so much as embodying the pitfalls of episodic models that may begin strong/weak or that rely on its future iterations for closure; instead, it should be remembered of how these stand-alone expansions can refine the mechanics of a finished game and continue the development of the future of a series by recusing their assets. 

[h1]Gordon & Alyx Went Up the Citadel to Fetch A Plot McGuffin[/h1]

Episode 1 begins immediately after the events of Half-Life 2’s ending where instead of fading off into obscurity yet again for the G-Man’s plans Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance are rescued from one dire situation and put into another. The two of them must escape the Citadel impending on its inevitable collapse by going through the bowels of the Citadel tower and escaping through City 17 from its remaining trainyard before the portal to the Combine’s home world opens again. Immediately following this minor victory is where the game ends the first episode at another cliffhanger ending that has become a staple of the series that leaves the player desiring another adventure for Gordon Freeman.

Something that has become more apparent with each chapter of the original Half-Life 2 and its episodes is that every level can be condensed down to one sentences about each level, and the series of chapters would read off as a synopsis rather than the full-scale story itself. EP1 is perhaps the most blatant of these set-ups as the game constantly paces the player with the simple objective of escaping the city with various deviations in the player that could be read off from the script as, “Gordon and Alyx were _____ when suddenly….” This isn’t so much a complaint about the obvious set-up of these level designs but it showcases how rather deceptively simple these campaigns are as the player is always given a clear direction and a current obstacle that makes every moment punctuated like the end of a sentence. What this really tells is not that the campaign itself needs to have an engaging storyline with complex narrative tricks but that structuring a Half-Life game is really closer to a bullet-list than a plot-structure where the level-design and gameplay obstacles are the main attraction.

This is perhaps why as short and sweet as EP1 is compared to the base game and EP2 are structured it’s why replaying EP1 is always a worthwhile turning point of the series because the level-design and set-pieces are as memorable as Ravenholm. Similar to Ravenholm and other linear levels of Half-Life 2 the sequences of EP1 are moment-to-moment obstacles that range from using the charged Gravity Gun to deactivate a reactor without guns to scavenging between a pistol, shotgun and gravity gun with Alyx in the bowels of the tower amongst the zombies and Antlions. These obstacles are largely combat-focused, including the puzzles themselves such as closing Antlion holes with cars, as well as working with Alyx and the other resistance members to fend off the waves of Combine as the remaining people make their escape. The result makes for a much more engaging experience than the many physics seesaw puzzles of the original game, and what was simply another excuse to get Gordon back on his feet yet again is one of the better sections of the entire Half-Life 2 experience.

[h1]”You Have Destroyed So Much, But What Have You Created? Can You Name One?”[/h1]

Other than the brevity of its campaign and its somewhat formulaic composition of an experience, the only bad things about Episode 1 itself is that it’s more of the same except more polished and more geared towards its combat, which are not bad things compared to the slower sections of Half-Life 2. Even the narrative elements, though few and far between compared to the base game and Episode 2, are condensed down into the only notes needed for the player to follow along that expands upon what players know about the lore of Half-Life. Compared to the insignificance of the first Half-Life expansions and how poorly Blue Shift was as a stand-alone title, EP1 does more to redeem itself from the ire of its fanbase. Perhaps the only thing it is guilty of much like Episode 2 is that it is doomed to repeat the same mistakes with its ending of holding the player’s attention long enough for a future sequel to continue where it previously left off and bringing up story-arcs that will likely never be given an in-game resolution to reward the player’s patience of the wait.

Half-Life 2: Episode One powstał w celu szybszej dystrybucji gier i krótszego czasu czekania na następne części, (Różnica między dwoma HLami trwała 6 lat) lecz równocześnie z tego powodu nadal nie mamy Half-Life'a 3. Dla niektórych to mógł być dobry pomysł, ale jak kto uważa. W grze znowu wcielamy się w Gordona Freemana i wraz z Alyx Vance będziemy musieli uciec z City 17, zanim całe wybuchnie. 

Grafika się postarzała, lecz w delikatny sposób, więc granie w nią nie sprawia bólu oczu jak w innych grach wydanych w tamtym czasie. Rozgrywka nadal jest dynamiczna, choc strzelanie wydaje się łatwiejsze niż jest w dzisiejszych grach. Muzyka jest skomponowana bardzo dobrze i pasuje do rozgrywanego poziomu, scenariusz Marca Laidlawa jest bardzo angażujący, gdyż w grach Valve scenariusz był pisany w taki sposób, aby gameplay nie wydawał się nudny i dlatego gra daje odgroma frajdy. 
Z wad produkcji, to jest jej długość, gdyż można przejść grę w 2-4 godziny oraz czasami podczas niektórych momentów można poczuć nudę. 

Zalety: 
- Grafika do dzisiaj nadal się nie postarzała się drastycznie
- Świetny gameplay
- Klimatyczna muzyka
- Dobra fabuła
- Daje dużo frajdy

Wady:
- Momentami jednak nudna :v
- Krótka (Może jakieś 3-4 godziny)

This game is majorly addictive once you first buy it and if you still love it (like me) you just use your spare time to do something related to this game. [h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

[b] THE CONTINUATION TO ONE OF THE BEST PC GAMES OF ALL TIME [/b]

This game is still awesome and fun to play even to this day, Half-Life 2: Episode One still stays one of the best FPS games on the PC. Released way back in 2006, Half-Life 2: Episode One was developed by Valve and originally published by Sierra Studios but now is self-published by Valve themselves and is a continuation to the widely popular Half-Life 2

Half-Life 2: Episode One offers solid controls with an interestingly told story and some interesting settings and unforgettable characters. The game is difficult and you will die a lot but with a little patience you will get through its 8 or so hour campaign

Half-Life 2: Episode One offers some good level design with a modding community which is still alive to this very day! And the game runs smoothly and runs fine on modern-day systems

And who of course forget the famous crowbar!

Incredibly, for a game that came out in 2006, the game's graphics and sound design have really aged well and you can tell if the game came out nowadays or in 2006 and with the Source engine, it has aged the game very well and has made it playable on almost every modern PC to date

Half-Life 2: Episode One is an instant classic and a must buy for every PC owner!
 
[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]
[i] THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!) [/i]

Excellent addition to Half-Life 2. Enjoyed tossing combine around with the overcharged zero-point energy gun. Enjoyed lighting zombines on fire with flares. I liked it more than Half-Life 2. It felt more focused, without any tedious and unnecessary gameplay moments. I also found the graphics considerably better. The negative side is the game is even more linear, stuffed with scripted scenes. At the end, I think this is a more polished game than the original, although pretty short.
